data.title: UCONN NEEDS A ‘BACK’-UP PLAN ; STAR OKAFOR ISN’T OK, AND THAT HURTS HUSKIES
data.meta_description: This was supposed to be Connecticut’s season, and the court was going to be Emeka Okafor’s personal playground, where he could take anyone’s...
data.text:
This was supposed to be Connecticut’s season, and the court was going to be Emeka Okafor’s personal playground, where he could take anyone’s ball and swat it away.

The Huskies – before Howard Dean growled like a caged Huskie, Justin Timberlake exposed Janet Jackson’s nipple ring, and Mike Jarvis was fired at St. John’s – were everyone’s preseason No. 1, led by regal and relentless Okafor.

Connecticut learned soon enough that life seldom goes according to plan. Freshman Charlie Villanueva’s eligibility was called into question early, then in an after-thought game against Sacred Heart, Okafor suffered a back injury.

He has been poked and prodded by more doctors than Elizabeth Taylor.

For a while, Okafor’s back loosened up and the 6-foot-9 junior with the wingspan of one of those prehistoric birds, showed why Emeka Okafor must translate into “I Own the Lane.”

In a late-season four-game stretch, he averaged 21 points and 14 rebounds. After he had a double-double at halftime of a 71-53 win over St. John’s in the Garden, Connecticut coach Jim Calhoun made Okafor’s case for Player of the Year.

“He is evolving into something awfully special,” Calhoun said after Okafor grabbed 22 rebounds against the Red Storm. “He is clearly the best player in America. Most importantly, he is the most valuable player in America.”

Connecticut (24-6) and the rest of the Big East is about to learn how valuable Okafor is. The league tournament begins today in the Garden with four first-round games. Seton Hall, led by Andre Barrett of The Bronx, and Villanova, led by Jason Fraser of Long Island, cap day one with the most intriguing matchup.

The Huskies will meet the winner of the Notre Dame-West Virginia game tomorrow, and Okafor’s status is uncertain. He clearly was in pain Sunday when the Huskies lost 67-56 at Syracuse.

Okafor, who had an MRI exam Monday, scored two points and grabbed nine rebounds against the Orangemen. There is no indication that additional rest will cure Okafor’s aching back.

“When he’s healthy, he’s the dominant player in college basketball,” Syracuse coach Jim Boeheim said. “When he’s healthy, [UConn] is the best team in college basketball. They’re still a good basketball team without him, but clearly, without him, it hurts them.”

Without a healthy Okafor, Pittsburgh, last year’s Big East tournament champ, has an excellent chance to repeat. The Panthers (27-3) are tougher than the Huskies to begin with.

Providence and Syracuse, the other teams with a first-round bye, will have to play exceptionally well to cut down the nets in the Garden on Saturday night. The Hall is a great dark-horse candidate to play for the title.

“There’s no dominant team,” Barrett said. “There are teams that have shown they can be dominating at times. It’s the team that’s most determined and focused that will win it.”

CHART: Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden

Odds & Ends

The Big East Tournament beings today at Madison Square Garden. The Post’s Lenn Robbins handicaps the field:

FAVORITES

Pittsburgh (27-3, 13-3, seeded 1st)

Chevy Troutman, Chris Taft, Toree Morris – big cats lurk in the tall grass.

Odds: 3-1

Connecticut (24-6, 12-4, seeded 2nd)

Because of Emeka Okafor’s bad back, the team chiropractor becomes the MVP.

Odds: 5-1

Syracuse (21-6, 11-5, seeded 4th)

Louis McCroskey of The Bronx and Demetrius Nichols are ripening oranges.

Odds: 10-1

Providence (20-7, 11-5, seeded 3rd)

Ryan’s Song: Friars need to refocus and find their Gomes-to guy.

Odds: 15-1

SLEEPERS

Seton Hall (20-8, 10-6, seeded 6th)

Will pay top dollar to see Andre Barrett cut down the Garden nets.

Odds: 15-1

Boston College (21-8, 10-6, seeded 5th)

Uka Agbai and Craig Smoth take their Bruise Brothers act to the Garden.

Odds: 20-1

Notre Dame (16-11, 9-7, seeded 7th)

3-ball, corner pocket; Irish attempted 37 treys vs St. John’s.

Odds: 20-1

West Virginia (15-12, 7-9, seeded 10th)

Un-Beilein-able: Coach throws leading scorer off the team; Mountaineers win seven league games.

Odds: 40-1

LONGSHOTS

Rutgers (16-11, 7-9, seeded 9th)

Gary Waters stars in Pirates of Piscataway.

Odds: 100-1

Villanova (14-15, 6-1, seeded 11th)

If loving you is Wright, why are the ‘Cats so wrong?

Odds: 250-1

Virginia Tech (14-13, 7-9, seeded 8th)

Enjoy the Garden, Hokies, because it’s the Greensboro Coliseum after this.

Odds: 500-1

Georgetown (13-14, 4-12, seeded 12th)

Hoya Paranoia has been eradicated.

Odds: Off the board
